awd_titl_txt: Stanford Program in Support of LIGO - Seismic Isolation and Controls
awd_abstract_narration:
In modern telescopes, much of the instrument's value lies in the stability of the mount and tracking.  This is especially true for the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) - the value of the suspension and isolation is paramount because the mirrors must be suspended above the shaking ground.  The work at Stanford is focused on the design and implementation of the mount that supports the optics for the 4-km long LIGO interferometer. The current facilities excel at isolating LIGO from the typical shaking of the ground; this grant will fund several related efforts to improve the robust operation of the LIGO detectors during large seismic disturbances, and it will also fund development of new techniques to isolate the optics of future, cryogenic detectors.

To improve the duty cycle of the existing observatories, this grant supports work to mitigate the impact of wind storms on the detectors by combining computational fluid dynamics, wind tunnel tests, and observatory field measurements to develop low-cost wind barriers and improved control algorithms. The grant also supports development and testing of novel control schemes to help improve the operation of the detector during large, teleseismic earthquakes. Recent work has shown that nearly 90% of the low frequency ground motion during an earthquake is common to all the optics in the detector. The new research will actively coordinate the motion of all the platforms to simultaneously minimize the common-mode drives and the differential-mode motion over the 4-km length of the observatory. The large reduction in control force, and the improvement in differential excursions is expected to significantly improve the overall robustness of the detector.  Stanford University operates the Engineering Test Facility, a 10-meter vacuum system with a prototype isolation system, where integrated hardware and software development for gravitational wave development is conducted. This grant funds research in this facility for seismic isolation of observatories which are now in the early planning stages. Future detectors are expected to use cooled optics to reduce the thermally driven (Brownian) noise of the mirrors. However, these mirrors will have more than a megawatt of laser power incident upon them, so running them at cryogenic temperatures requires the ability to continuous remove significant thermal energy. Techniques to do this will be tested on the prototype isolation platform so that the requirements for cooling and vibration control can be developed and tested simultaneously.

por.por_cntn:
The exceptional performance of the Advanced LIGO Interferometers is the foundation on which the new field of gravitational wave astronomy is being built. Our group, collaborating with the LIGO Lab and the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC), has undertaken several activities to improve the robust operation and low frequency performance of the Advanced LIGO (aLIGO) detectors and for future gravitational wave detectors.

 

Modeling of Thermal Noise Induced by Electrostatic Coupling

We developed a new framework to model thermal noise induced by the interaction of electric charge on the LIGO optic with nearby lossy conductors, such as the LIGO electrostatic drives (ESD) or the LIGO Suspension cages. Although charging of the LIGO optics is a known problem, careful calculation of the noise impact from charge had never been done. The new framework allows this calculation to be done rigorously, and uses a new ?electrostatic reciprocity? result to relate force applied to the optic via the ESD to the current induced in the ESD by charge on the moving optic. This equivalence means that the loss can be well estimated with either FEA models or measurements of the ESD drive response. We used the measured response to show the thermal noise term is now about an order of magnitude below the aLIGO sensitivity curve.

 

Seismic Platform Interferometry

Our group has a long interest in developing a Seismic Platform Interferometer (SPI) to improve low frequency performance of aLIGO by measuring and controlling relative motion between seismic isolation tables. We are collaborating with the Albert Einstein Institute to adapt the system used at their lab for use in aLIGO.  We have shown how to replace the sophisticated electronics previously used with software running on the LIGO data acquisition and control systems ? this outcome reduces cost and complexity. This work has also prompted a new collaboration with scientists at the SLAC National Accelerator Facility to implement an SPI on an X-ray optical setup and evaluate how the technology can improve beam pointing and energy stability for SLAC?s new developmental X-ray sources.

 

Noise Study of the Signal Recycling Cavity

We studied both LIGO detectors to explore how implementation of an SPI could improve the Signal Recycling Cavity Length (SRCL), an auxiliary optical cavity used to improve aLIGO performance. We showed that an SPI could improve the stability of the SRCL cavity below 0.7 Hz. In this study we also demonstrated that, above 0.7 Hz, the seismic table motion does not dominate SRCL length noise, and we identified several other important noise sources. This is an important outcome because the SCRL length is a limiting noise source for aLIGO.   

 

Wind Fence Evaluation

Several years ago, the Stanford group proposed a wind fence design to protect the two End Stations at the LIGO Hanford Observatory (LHO) from wind-driven building tilt. The LIGO Lab worked with a vendor to design and install fences in October 2019, and we evaluated the performance of the new fences. The fences have dramatically reduced the tilt of the End Stations. The fences, in concert with the ground tilt sensors developed at the University of Washington, have effectively eliminated tilt as a problem for the seismic system in these buildings, and now the largest impact of wind induced tilt is in the LHO corner station.  

 

Improved Control during Earthquakes

Teleseismic earthquakes (ie earthquakes more than 1000 km away) are the largest known source of downtime for the aLIGO detectors. In coordination with the Observatories, we developed and implemented a novel control scheme to improve the robustness of the detectors during earthquakes. Before this system was installed, the observatories would lose lock several times each week from these events. The new control earthquake control is running at both LIGO detectors, and the amplitude of ground shaking during which the detectors can run has nearly doubled since the first Observing run.

 

Cryogenic cooling and vibration control for future detectors

Reducing the optics? temperature could reduce the thermal noise of future detectors. In previous grants we demonstrated a system to radiatively cool a silicon optic with good vibration control of the cold shield. During this grant we extended that work by demonstrating two methods of rapidly cooling the optic. Both systems utilize dilute nitrogen exchange gas between the mirror and the innermost cold shield. First, we controlled the pressure in the main volume by feeding gas into the inner shield and differentially pumping the volume between the inner and the outer shields. Although effective, this requires complicated mechanics. For our second prototype, we built a collapsible membrane enclosure to surround both shields. When this enclosure is filled with dilute nitrogen, we rapidly cooled the optic while maintaining adequate vacuum in the main volume. The demonstration of this improved technique is an important outcome for the design of future low temperature detectors.
